Polyoxometalate-embedded copper-organic network as dual-site synergetic catalyst for the selective oxidation of benzylic C−H bond Yue Wang Writing – original draft Validation Investigation Data curation Qian Liu Writing – original draft Validation Investigation Data curation Yuan-Yuan Ma Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Supervision Funding acquisition Conceptualization ⁎ Ze-Xuan Liu Writing – original draft Validation Investigation Data curation Ya-Nan Zhang Writing – review & editing Validation Investigation Data curation Yu-Shuo Wang Writing – review & editing Validation Investigation Data curation Jing Du Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Supervision Funding acquisition Conceptualization ⁎ Zhan-Gang Han Writing – review & editing Supervision Project administration Funding acquisition Conceptualization ⁎ Hebei Technology Innovation Center for Energy Conversion Materials and Devices, National Demonstration Center for Experimental Chemistry Education, Testing and Analysis Center, College of Chemistry and Materials Science, Hebei Normal University, Shijiazhuang, Hebei 050024, PR China Hebei Technology Innovation Center for Energy Conversion Materials and Devices National Demonstration Center for Experimental Chemistry Education Testing and Analysis Center College of Chemistry and Materials Science Hebei Normal University Shijiazhuang Hebei 050024 PR China Hebei Technology Innovation Center for Energy Conversion Materials and Devices, National Demonstration Center for Experimental Chemistry Education, Testing and Analysis Center, College of Chemistry and Materials Science, Hebei Normal University, Shijiazhuang, Hebei 050024, PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Selective activation and oxidization of inert C−H bonds into value-added chemicals affords attractively economic and ecological benefits, as well as central challenge in modern synthetic chemistry. Herein, by integrating the redox polyoxometalate (POM) centers and multinuclear copper sites in one system, four compounds were constructed with formulas of [Cu2(μ 2-Cl)(H2O)2L3][PM12O40]·4H2O (M = Mo for 1, W for 2), and [Cu4(μ 2-OH)4L2] [H3PM11CuO40]·12H2O (M = Mo for 3, W for 4, L = 1,4-di[4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl]-benzene). Both compounds 1–2 exhibited 3-D POM-embedded supramolecular networks constructed by discrete [PM12O40]3− clusters and binuclear {Cu2(μ 2-Cl)(N–N)2} unit-based metal-organic sheets. While compounds 3–4 displayed 3-D POM-supported supramolecular networks composed of monosubstituted Keggin-type anions [H3PM11CuO40]4− and {Cu2(μ 2-OH)(N–N)2} chain-based metal-organic layers. Four crystalline structures with distinct dual-active site distribution showed significant peroxidase-like activities owing to the collaborative catalysis of multinuclear copper units and polyanionic clusters, which can smoothly catalyze the C−H bond oxidation of diphenylmethane to benzophenone with ca. 97 % conversion and >98 % selectivity within 24 h. Notably, the monosubstituted [H3PM11CuO40]4−-based compounds 3−4 showed higher catalytic activities than [PM12O40]3−-based compounds 1−2 (88 % conversion and >97 % selectivity within 12 h). This kind of crystalline structures also showed good recoverability. The synergetic reaction mechanism was also explored. This work provides a new strategy to design robust heterogeneous POM-based synergetic catalysts for C−H bond functionalization. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Polyoxometalate Metal-organic network C−H bond oxidation Heterogeneous catalysis Synergetic catalyst Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The activation and selective oxidation of inert C−H bonds represents one of the most fundamental chemical transformations in modern organic synthesis for value-added oxidized products [1-3]. The selective oxidation of C–H bond to form ketone is one of the key research areas. Ketones are a kind of important intermediates in the synthesis of pharmaceuticals, natural products, agrochemicals, dyes, and other fine chemicals [4,5]. Most of traditional methods for C–H bond oxidation to ketone derivatives need stoichiometric amount of strong oxidants, such as potassium permanganate, chromium reagents, etc. However, there are multiple problems with the use of these oxidants for reactions, such as by-products, troublesome post-treatment, and significant environmental pollution [5]. Therefore, the exploration of efficient catalyst system for the selective oxidation of C–H bond to form ketone is highly desired. Polyoxometalates (POMs) have been recognized as promising green functional materials in various fields of catalysis [6-24], sensing [25,26], energy [27], medicines and tumor therapy [28,29], owing to their attractive merits of adjustable acid/base, redox property, and excellent stability [30-36]. Especially, POMs possess specific peroxidase-mimicking activity, which can effectively activate and convert the peroxides to reactive oxygen species for selective oxidation of organic substrates via multistep electron-transfer process [35,37]. For example, Mizuno and co-workers reported a divanadium- substituted phosphotungstate [γ-H2PV2W10O40]3− to realize specific, regioselective, H2O2-based hydroxylation of secondary C–H bonds [38]. Neumann et al. isolated a dicobalt(IV)-μ-oxo phosphotungstate [(α 2-P2W17O61Co)2O]14−, which was the reactive species for selective oxidation of alcohols by C–H bond activation [39]. Han et al. reported a kind of bio-based POM hybrids via the assembly of the natural phytic acid with MoO3, which achieved the efficient aerobic oxidation of benzylic C(sp3)–H bonds to corresponding carbonyl compounds [40]. Recently, copper-based compounds as artificial metalloenzyme systems have high activities to cleave inert specific C−H bonds for further oxidation [41-44]. Lin et al. integrated an binuclear copper monooxygenase with Ti-MOF that could cooperatively stabilize the Cu-O2 adduct for O−O bond cleavage, displaying catalytic performance toward various C−H bond oxidation processes [45]. Schrӧder reported a paddlewheel-like [Cu2 II(O2CR)4] node-based MOF, in which can activate tert‑butyl hydrogen peroxide (TBHP) via the partial reduction of itself into [CuICuII(O2CR)4] species to oxidize the C–H bonds in benzylic compounds [46]. Considering the advantages of POMs and copper sites in activating peroxide for C–H bond oxidation, incorporating POM clusters into the active copper-organic networks, would provide a potential efficient strategy to achieve the synergistic promotion of catalytic performance. POMs possess abundant surface-active oxygen species and high negative charge that can be easily assemble into copper-organic network to construct multiple active sites for target reactions [47-49]. For instance, Liu's group demonstrated a copper(II)/{PMo12} homogeneous catalytic system that can effectively induce the production of tert‑butanol radical intermediate for the selective oxidation of benzylic C–H bonds to ketones with good functional group tolerance and high chemical selectivity [50]. The experimental results revealed that the catalytic synergy of copper(II)/{PMo12} could improve the selectivity for benzylic C–H bond oxidation, and both copper(II) and {PMo12} could promote the decomposition of TBHP to form tert‑butanol radicals for accelerating the conversion of ethylbenzene to acetophenone. Wang and co-workers reported a kind of Cu/POM complexes for catalytic diphenylmethane with >92 % conversion and 100 % selectivity towards benzophenone [51]. Chang et al. demonstrated Cu/POM coordination polymers could selectively catalyze the oxidation of substituted phenols to p-benzoquinones with H2O2 [52]. These significant advances corroborate the advantages of integrating POMs and copper sites in enhancing catalytic performance [53-55]. However, the copper sites in these currently reported compounds are mainly distributed in metal-organic fragments. Exploring the influence of the relative position of copper sites in POM-based copper-organic compounds (copper-organic network or POM cluster self) on the catalytic performance, will provide another pathway for developing efficient dual-site synergetic catalysts. Based on above mentioned analysis, four POM-embedded copper-organic networks were synthesized and used as dual-site synergetic catalysts for benzylic C−H oxidation. The formulas are [Cu2(μ 2-Cl)(H2O)2L3][PM12O40]·4H2O (M = Mo for 1, W for 2), and [Cu4(μ 2-OH)4L2] [H3PM11CuO40]·12H2O (M = Mo for 3, W for 4) (L = 1,4-di[4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl]-benzene, denoted as DTAB). Compounds 1 and 2 possess similar structures and exhibit three-dimensional (3-D) POM-embedded networks constructed by binuclear {Cu2(μ 2-Cl)(N–N)2} unit-based 2-D networks and [PM12O40]3− clusters. Compounds 3 and 4 possess similar 2-D copper-organic cationic layers containing unique {Cu2(μ 2-OH)(N–N)2} chains, that were further intercalated by monosubstituted [H3PM11CuO40]4− clusters into 3-D supramolecular structures. Four compounds provide distinct structural models to explore the influence of copper site positions on catalytic performance. Experiments showed that compounds 1–4 can efficiently activate H2O2 and TBHP to decompose into strong oxidizing groups to oxidize 3,3′,5,5′-tetramethylbenzidine (TMB) solution to blue. Taking the C−H bond oxidation of diphenylmethane (DPM) as a model reaction, four compounds displayed excellent heterogeneous catalytic activity and high product selectivity. The monosubstituted [H3PM11CuO40]4−-based compounds 3−4 showed higher catalytic activities with 88 % conversion of DPM and >97 % selectivity to benzophenone within 12 h than that of [PM12O40]3−-based compounds 1−2. Moreover, these compounds as heterogeneous catalysts demonstrated high stability and excellent recoverability. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Synthesis of compounds 1–4 Compounds 1–4 were synthesized by hydrothermal methods using CuCl2·H2O, H3PM12O40·xH2O (M = W, Mo), DTAB as raw materials, and acetonitrile was added to the reaction system to adjust the solubility of the ligand. During the synthetic process, the reaction temperature and pH condition played key roles in the formation of four compounds. The optimized parameters were as follows: compounds 1–2 were synthesized under lower reaction temperature (120 °C) and pH environments (1.5 for 1 and 4.8 for 2), while compounds 3–4 were isolated under higher reaction temperatures (160 and 180 °C) and pH conditions (2.6 for 3 and 5.1 for 4). Under such high reaction temperature and pH condition, the monosubstituted Keggin-type [H3PM11CuO40]4− anions were in-situ synthesized via a dissociation-reassembly process in compounds 3–4. DTAB ligand provides four potential coordination sites to bond with Cu2+ ions for the generation of cationic copper-organic network, which could interact with POM polyoxoanions for facilitating the formation of synergetic catalytic systems. 2.2 Structure of compounds 1–4 Single crystal X-ray analyses revealed that compounds 1 and 2 possess similar structures and adopt a POM-embedded 3-D supramolecular network (Table S1 and Figures S1–S2). Taking compound 1 as an example, there are two crystallographically independent Cu centers (Cu1 and Cu2), which are six-coordinated by four nitrogen donors from four DTAB ligands, one μ 2-Cl atom and one coordinated water molecule to form a distorted octahedral configuration (Figure S1). The Cu–N bond length ranges from 1.986(6) Å to 2.031(6) Å, and the N–Cu–N angle varies from 85.6(3)° to 175.7(3)°. The distance of Cu–Cl bond is 2.598(2) Å, and the bond angle of N–Cu–Cl is in the range of 86.16(18)°–96.51(19)° (Tables S2–S3). In compound 1, the DTAB ligands display three kinds of coordination modes, which can be divided into three groups: ‘pyrazole-like’ four-connection ligand (4c-L), two-connection ligand with trans-configuration (trans-2c-L) and two-connection ligand with cis-configuration (cis-2c-L) (Figure S3). Cu1 and Cu2 centers are bridged by one μ 2-Cl atom and two N–N fragments from two 4c-L to compose a unique di-nuclear {Cu2 (μ 2-Cl)(N–N)2} unit (Fig. 1a ). The binuclear {Cu2(μ 2-Cl)(N–N)2} units serve as a four-connected node and further connect with two trans-2c-L and two cis-2c-L to form a 2-D metal-organic layer on the bc plane (Fig. 1b). The 2-D layers possess rhombic shaped windows with size of 13.02 × 13.05 Å (Fig. 1c) and present a sql-type 4-c topological net with point symbol of {44.62}. The large quadrilateral pore size and abundant aromatic rings provide a confined environment to stabilize non-coordinated [PMo12O40]3− clusters via plentiful C–H…O and O–H…O hydrogen bonding interactions, which would accelerate the energy transport and electron transfer between the two active sites during oxidation catalysis (Fig. 1c and Tables S4–S5). The 2-D layers are parallelly stacked along a axis with [PMo12O40]3− clusters in ‘egg-in-box’ fashion to extend into 3-D supramolecular framework structure (Fig. 1d). Compounds 3 and 4 are also isostructural and belong to the monoclinic P21/c space group (Table S1 and Figure S4–S5). Exemplifying compound 3 as an example, the asymmetric structural unit of compound 3 consists of half mono-substituted Keggin-type [H3PMo11CuO40]4− polyanion, two CuII cations (Cu1 and Cu2), two μ 2-O atoms and two DTAB ligands (Figure S4a). In compound 3, both Cu1 and Cu2 centers adopt nearly planar quadrilateral configurations and are four-coordinated by two μ 2-O atoms and two nitrogen donors from two DTAB (4c-L) ligands, with Cu–N/O bond lengths of 1.890(10) Å–2.007(9) Å and N/O–Cu–N/O angle ranges of 87.0(4)°–178.1(4)° (Figure S4b and Tables S6-S7). The adjacent Cu centers are bridged by μ 2-O donors to form a one-dimensional (1-D) Cu–O–Cu chain with bi-nuclear {Cu2(μ 2-OH)(N–N)2} units (Fig. 2a –2b), which are further supported by DTAB ligands (4c-L) via ‘pyrazole-like’ connection mode to extend out to 2-D wavy layers along c axis (Fig. 2c). These 2-D sheets feature uninodal 4-c kgm/Shubnikov plane nets with {32.62.72} topology (Figure S6). The abundant aromatic rings on 2-D sheets induce strong non-covalent intermolecular interactions with [H3PMo11CuO40]4− clusters via plentiful C–H…O and O–H…O hydrogen bonds (Tables S8–S9), which could enlarge the synergistic effect between two active sites for C–H bond oxidation (Fig. 2d). Finally, [H3PMo11CuO40]4− clusters as guests are distributed between the parallel-stacked 2-D layers to construct the 3-D supramolecular network (Fig. 2e). Notably, in 3-D network the {Cu2(μ 2-OH)(N–N)2} sites are not blocked by POM clusters, which are accessible in catalytic reaction. Generally, four compounds displayed 3-D POM-embedded copper-organic networks based on Keggin-type polyoxoanions and {Cu-DTAB} 2-D cationic sheets. Integrating the dual sites of copper ion and POM clusters provides promising synergetic catalysts for benzylic C–H bond oxidation. Moreover, this kind of structures provide different distribution of copper sites (metal-organic sheet or POM cluster) and clear catalytic model for studying structure-performance relationships. 2.3 Physical characterizations of compounds 1–4 In order to verify the structures and compositions of compounds 1–4, infrared spectroscopy (IR), powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) and thermogravimetric analysis (TG) were carried out. As shown in Figure S7, the characteristic absorption peaks of Keggin-type polyoxoanions (1060–802 cm−1) and organic DTAB ligands (1640–1538 cm−1) could be observed in IR spectra [6,8,41]. XRD test results showed that the experimental diffraction patterns of compounds 1–4 were basically consistent with the theoretical simulation, suggesting the good crystallinity of them (Figure S8). Bond valence sums calculations demonstrated that Cu ions are in +2 oxidation state and Mo/W atoms are in +6 oxidation state (Tables S10–S13). TG analysis revealed that the main structures of compounds 1–4 can be maintained about 280 °C, implying their good thermal stability (Figure S9). 2.4 Peroxide activation activity of compounds 1–4 Given that H2O2 or TBHP are common peroxide oxidants in benzylic C–H bond oxidation, the peroxide activation activities of compounds 1–4 were examined. By tracking the UV–Vis absorbance at a wavelength of 654 nm, which corresponds to the oxidation product of 3,3′,5,5′-tetramethylbenzidine (TMB) substrate in the presence of H2O2 or TBHP, can indicate the reactive oxygen species (ROS) generated by the activation of H2O2 or TBHP over these compounds. As shown in Fig. 3a , when compounds 1–4 presented in TMB+H2O2 system, the distinct absorption peaks corresponding to the oxidized TMB (oxTMB) appeared at 654 nm along with the solution color changes to blue. This result suggested that compounds 1–4 can activate H2O2 decomposition to produce active oxygen species for TMB oxidation (Fig. 3a). Similarly, TMB oxidation reactions were also conducted over compounds 1–4 in presence of TBHP. As shown in Fig. 3b, the color of TMB-TBHP systems rapidly changed from colorless to blue after the addition of compounds 1–4, demonstrating their high TBHP activation capacity. Notably, the absorbance intensity of oxTMB in TMB-TBHP systems is obviously higher than that in TMB-H2O2 system. The enhanced affinity of compounds 1–4 for TBHP molecule may be caused by the abundant aromatic groups in hybrid structures. Furthermore, a series of control experiments were conducted to explore the origin of the catalytic peroxide activation activity of compounds 1–4. As shown in Fig. 3c, the absorbance of the solution is negligible in the absence of peroxides or catalysts. When the cesium salt of [PM12O40]3− and CuO were presented in the TMB-TBHP system, the absorbance at 654 nm was distinctly enhanced, indicating that both POM anions and copper sites play key roles in activating TBHP molecules. Compared to the raw materials, compounds 1–4 exhibit stronger absorbance intensity, suggesting that there is synergistic catalytic effect between POM clusters and copper-organic networks. It should also be pointed out that the [H3PM11CuO40]4−-based compounds 3–4 show higher catalytic activities than [PM12O40]3−-based compounds 1–2, which indicated that the advantage of monosubstituted POM for peroxide activation. In addition, to disclose the reactive oxygen species in TMB-TBHP system, the radical quenchers (isopropanol (IPA) for ·OH, hydroquinone (HQ) for ·O2 − and ascor bic acid (AA) for all types of ROS) were introduced to the reaction system. After adding IPA, HQ and AA, the intensities of oxTMB are severely weakened (Fig. 3d and 3e). These results demonstrated that the ∙O2 − and ∙OH are major ROS in TBHP activation process, which are beneficial for the following C–H bond oxidation reaction. 2.5 Catalytic oxidation of benzylic C–H bond Given the high TBHP activation activity of compounds 1–4, the benzylic C–H bond oxidation performance was evaluated using diphenylmethane (DPM) as model substrate and TBHP as the oxidant. Before the catalytic reaction, the particle sizes of four crystalline compounds were measured by scanning electron microscope (SEM). As shown in Figure S10, compounds 1–4 show similar particle size distributions with the average size of 0.3 μm, excluding the influence of particle size on catalytic performance. Then, the reaction conditions such as solvent, TBHP dosage, reaction temperature and catalyst dosage were optimized by using compound 1 as representative catalyst. Fig. 4a showed the catalytic oxidation results of DPM at 75 °C in four organic solvents: ethyl acetate, methanol, ethanol and acetonitrile. The conversions of DPM oxidation in ethyl acetate, methanol and ethanol were only 20 %, 21 % and 38 %, and the selectivity of the target product benzophenone (BP) was only 84 %, 60 % and 77 %, respectively, with diphenylmethanol as by-product. When acetonitrile is used as the reaction solvent, the conversion of DPM can reach 84 % and the selectivity of BP can reach 97 %. Compared with other reaction solvents, the catalyst in acetonitrile has the highest conversion of the substrate and the best selectivity of the target product. Therefore, acetonitrile solvent was selected as the best reaction solvent for catalyzing DPM conversion. Subsequently, the effect of the amount of TBHP oxidant on the catalytic performance was investigated using acetonitrile as the reaction solvent. Fig. 4b showed the relationship between the conversion and selectivity and the amount of TBHP in the range of 0.3–3.2 mmol. With the TBHP usage of 0.3 mmol, the conversion of DPM reaches ca. 47 %, which was close to the stoichiometric value, suggesting the production of active oxygen species limits the catalytic performance. With the increase of TBHP dosage from 0.8 mmol to 3.2 mmol, the conversion of DPM increased from 61 % to 85 %. This result indicates that with the increase of TBHP content, more t BuO· and ·OH will be generated during the catalytic reaction to oxidize DPM. Although the conversion rate of TBHP at 2.4 mmol was 84 % lower than that at 3.2 mmol, it had the best BP selectivity (97 %) at 2.4 mmol. Therefore, the optimal dosage of TBHP was determined to be 2.4 mmol. For the DPM oxidation system catalyzed by TBHP as oxidant, it is also very important to explore the effect of reaction temperature on the catalytic performance. As shown in Fig. 4c, the conversion of DPM increased from 55 % to 96 % in the range of 60–80 °C and the selectivity increased from 79 % to 98 %. Therefore, the optimum reaction temperature is 80 °C. The effect of the catalyst amount on the catalytic performance was also studied. With the increase of catalyst dosage from 10 mg to 20 mg, the conversion of DPM increased from 81 % to 96 %, and the selectivity of BP increased from 93 % to 99 %. However, when the amount of catalyst further increased to 30 mg, the conversion of DPM only increased to 99 % (Fig. 4d). Considering the economy of the catalytic reaction, 20 mg was selected as the optimal dosage of the catalyst. In summary, the optimized reaction conditions are obtained with acetonitrile as solvent, TBHP (2.4 mmol), reaction temperature of 80 °C and the catalyst loading of 20 mg. Under the optimal reaction conditions, four compounds displayed excellent catalytic activities for the oxidation of benzylic C–H bond that smoothly converted DPM to BP product with high selectivity and fast kinetics (Figs. 5a and 5b). The conversions of DPM within 24 h were 96 % for 1, 96 % for 2, 97 % for 3–4, and the selectivity of BP were 98 %, 97 %, 97 % and 98 %, respectively (Table 1 , entries 1–4). The reaction rates (k) for four compounds are 0.13 h −1 for 1, 0.13 h −1 for 2, 0.14 h −1 for 3, 0.15 h −1 for 4, respectively. Notably, there are variations in catalytic performance for compounds 1–4. [PM12O40]3−-based compounds 1–2 showed ca. 79 % and 78 % conversion of DPM in 12 h, while [H3PM11CuO40]4−-based compounds 3–4 affords DPM conversions of ca. 88 % for 3 and 86 % for 4 within 12 h. These results revealed that the secondary Cu2+ ion in monosubstituted [H3PM11CuO40]4− cluster and accessible Cu-DTAB sites may assist in the adsorption and activation of substrate molecules and active oxygen species, thus improving the catalytic performance [56–59]. The blank reaction only gave ca. 3 % conversion rate of DPM in the absence of any catalyst (Table 1, entry 5), verifying the high catalytic performance of four compounds for the oxidation of benzylic C–H bonds. To explore the activity origin of four compounds, a series of control samples including POM salts, copper salt and DTAB ligand were selected to evaluate the catalytic performance of each component. CsxH3-xPMo12O40 and CsxH3-xPW12O40 as heterogeneous catalysts afforded moderate DPM conversions of 42 % and 41 % with high selectivity >85 % (Table 1, entries 6–7) in 12 h. Copper salt (CuCl2·2H2O) employed as homogeneous catalyst caused a 29 % conversion of DPM with the selectivity of 84 % (Table 1, entry 8). The DTAB ligand only achieved 5 % conversion of DPM and 97 % selectivity, which is similar to the blank experiment (Table 1, entry 9). Moreover, the mechanical mixtures of PMo12/CuCl2 and PW12/CuCl2 with same equivalent only showed ca. 47 % and 45 % conversions of DPM with >92 % BP selectivity, which were slightly higher than the single POM or copper salt, but far inferior to compounds 1–4 (Fig. 5c; Table 1, entry 10–11). The above results demonstrated that both copper sites and POM clusters are active for the conversion of DPM oxidation to BP. The formation of hybrid structures in compounds 1–4 induce significant synergistic effect for the performance promotion. Furthermore, to specify the advantages of POM supported copper species over other oxides supported copper species, two kinds of CuO/MoO3 and CuO/WO3 composite materials were synthesized and evaluated the catalytic performance toward the oxidation of DPM. As shown in Table 1, entries 13–14, CuO/MoO3 and CuO/WO3 showed ca. 69 % and 65 % conversions of DPM with the corresponding selectivity of 94 % and 92 % for BP. Compared to these materials, compounds 1–4 exhibited better catalytic activities, which imply that the molecular scale distribution of copper species on POM-based support is helpful to enhance the catalytic performance of materials (Table S14). To clarify the reactive intermediate species involved in DPM oxidation process over these compounds, a series of radical trapping experiments were performed by employing active compound 1 as catalyst. First, 1,4-benzoquinone (p-BQ) and IPA as ∙O2 − and ∙OH scavengers were introduced to the reaction system. It can be found that when p-BQ was added, a distinct decrease in DPM conversion (21 %) was observed, and the addition of IPA caused a decrease of DPM conversion to 37 % (Fig. 6a ). These results disclosed that ∙O2 − and ∙OH play important role in the DPM oxidation process (Fig. 6b). Moreover, the electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) measurements in Fig. 6b also captured the ∙O2 − and ∙OH free radicals. These results further proved the oxidation reaction undergoes a radical mechanism [60]. To further determine the origin of these oxygen radicals, N‑tert-Butyl-α-phenylnitrone (PBN) was added in the reaction system. In absence of catalyst, the introduction of PBN in DPM-TBHP system produced a weak radical signal that could be ascribed to the characteristic of PBN/ t BuOO∙ adduct (Fig. 6c). With the presence of compound 1, the signal intensity has greatly improved, further verifying the high activation activity of dual-site synergetic catalysts for TBHP. In addition, the substrates with different bond disassociated energy (85.9 Kcal/mol for indane, 83.6 Kcal/mol for tetraline, 82.5 Kcal/mol for phthalan) were selected to understand the oxidation reaction mechanism of C(sp3)–H bonds. As shown in Fig. 6d, the yields of the products exhibited a linear relationship with the BDE of the substrate. It indicated the C(sp3)–H bond activation is a rate-determining step, and the hydrogen atom transfer dominates the C(sp3)–H bond oxidization. Based on the above results, the possible mechanism for DPM oxidation catalyzed by compound 1 was proposed (Fig. 6e). In compounds 1–4, both copper site and POM cluster serve as synergetic active centers to activate and convert TBHP into the t BuOO∙, t BuO∙ and ∙OH radical for catalyzing DPM oxidation. Concretely, the POM site were first activated by oxidants to form the active species peroxo-Mo/W, and then the nucleophilic carbon atom in DPM was attacked by peroxo-Mo/W to form an unstable intermediate, which was easily transformed into another unstable intermediate through intramolecular electron transfer. The intermediate can be quickly released to generate BP. In this process, POMs returned to their original form and completed the catalytic cycle. The Cu site first interacts with DPM to form an electron-deficient DPM intermediate, and Cu(II) is reduced to Cu(I). Subsequently, TBHP obtains an electron from Cu(I) to generate tert‑butanol and ·OH, and Cu(I) is oxidized to Cu(II) (Fig. 6e) [23,46,61]. The ∙OH radical with high bond disassociation energy (BDE) can abstract a hydrogen atom from C–H bond of DPM to form an acyl radical. The carbon-center radical could react with TBHP molecules to form t BuOO∙-substrate adduct or peroxy radical, which release a t BuOH molecule to produce benzylic ketones. The scope of substrates in this reaction system was also examined under standard conditions. As shown in Table 2 , the conversion and selectivity of ethylbenzene reaction for 24 h were 86 % and 97 %, respectively. The conversion of ethylbenzene derivatives with electron-withdrawing nitro group was 68 %. The conversion and product selectivity of ethylbenzene derivatives with electron-donating (-CH3) group over compound 1 reached 87 % and 88 % within 24 h. The fluorene with greater steric hindrance gave a conversion of 99 % with the fluorenone selectivity of 98 %. These results implied that compound 1 as a dual-site synergetic catalyst performs well for benzylic C–H oxidation. To assess the heterogeneity of these materials, the thermal filtration experiment was carried out by choosing compound 1 as a representative. As shown in Fig. 7a , the catalyst was thermally filtered from the reaction system after 4 h of reaction, and the obtained mixed solution continued to react for 20 h. The conversion of DPM was increased by only 5 % in the following 20 h, indicating that compound 1 has good heterogeneous catalytic properties. Compound 1 could also be effectively reused for seven times with no distinctly decrease, revealing its good recyclability (Fig. 7b). The structure of catalyst after oxidation reaction was also investigated. The IR and XRD spectra of compound 1 before and after catalysis matched well, verifying the potential practicality of these dual-site synergetic catalysts for C−H oxidation reaction (Figs. 7c-d). 3 Conclusion In summary, a kind of POM-embedded copper-organic networks as dual-site synergetic catalysts were constructed, which present 3-D POM-embedded supramolecular network constructed by discrete Keggin-type [PM12O40]3− or [H3PM11CuO40]4− clusters and copper-organic sheets. Their well-defined structure features provide distinct model for exploring the influence of the relative position of copper sites on the catalytic performance. In compounds 1−4, the copper-organic units and POM clusters synergistically activated the H2O2 and TBHP oxidants to produce active reactive oxygen species, which displayed excellent catalytic performance for the oxidation of benzylic C−H bonds. This kind of dual-site synergetic catalyst systems showed >97 % conversion of DPM and BP selectivity (>98 %) as well as good recyclability and stability. The monosubstituted [H3PM11CuO40]4−-based compounds 3−4 showed higher catalytic activities than [PM12O40]3−-based compounds 1−2. This work provides a promising strategy for the development of efficient POM-based synergetic catalysts for C−H bond oxidation. coredata.dc:description: Selective activation and oxidization of inert C−H bonds into value-added chemicals affords attractively economic and ecological benefits, as well as central challenge in modern synthetic chemistry. Herein, by integrating the redox polyoxometalate (POM) centers and multinuclear copper sites in one system, four compounds were constructed with formulas of [Cu2(μ 2-Cl)(H2O)2L3][PM12O40]·4H2O (M = Mo for 1, W for 2), and [Cu4(μ 2-OH)4L2] [H3PM11CuO40]·12H2O (M = Mo for 3, W for 4, L = 1,4-di[4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl]-benzene). Both compounds 1–2 exhibited 3-D POM-embedded supramolecular networks constructed by discrete [PM12O40]3− clusters and binuclear {Cu2(μ 2-Cl)(N–N)2} unit-based metal-organic sheets. While compounds 3–4 displayed 3-D POM-supported supramolecular networks composed of monosubstituted Keggin-type anions [H3PM11CuO40]4− and {Cu2(μ 2-OH)(N–N)2} chain-based metal-organic layers. Four crystalline structures with distinct dual-active site distribution showed significant peroxidase-like activities owing to the collaborative catalysis of multinuclear copper units and polyanionic clusters, which can smoothly catalyze the C−H bond oxidation of diphenylmethane to benzophenone with ca. 97 % conversion and >98 % selectivity within 24 h. Notably, the monosubstituted [H3PM11CuO40]4−-based compounds 3−4 showed higher catalytic activities than [PM12O40]3−-based compounds 1−2 (88 % conversion and >97 % selectivity within 12 h). This kind of crystalline structures also showed good recoverability. The synergetic reaction mechanism was also explored. This work provides a new strategy to design robust heterogeneous POM-based synergetic catalysts for C−H bond functionalization.
